> [{quoted}](name=Riot Socrates,realm=NA,application-id=Ag8jgd8Q,discussion-id=ffY8IMgK,comment-id=00130002,timestamp=2015-03-11T20:56:43.906+0000)
>
> There are no demotions planned currently. This isn't intended to be a ranked system in the same sense as leagues. The grading system does give players an idea of how they are improving with a champion via the per game performance evaluation. Also, performance and winning or losing does dramatically effect gains and losses, so a high performing player will unlock rewards much more quickly.

Wouldn't the most "accurate" assessment of Champion skill be based on a person's Champion-specific Team Builder MMR, relative to their base MMR? If the concept of Champion expertise is defined principally as how much Champion-specific ability a person has?

I get the idea of wanting to acknowledge and reward investment of time and energy into learning a Champion, but I'm not entirely clear on what Riot's aiming for here. Is the idea to tell the team, "This person is going to be playing above their usual level this match, because they're on a Champion they're really good at"? Or just to give people bragging rights about their familiarity with a Champion? Or what?

If a person has played thousands of games with a really weak Champion, and actually does better with other Champions they're less familiar with, would they be getting this distinction? What if the ratio between their Champ-specific MMR and their general MMR is much better than most others have with that Champion? What if much worse?

It's just that "being good at a Champ" is actually kind of an ambiguous concept. I suppose I'm also a bit irked because there's a lot of shallow analysis that goes on in LoL with regard to, e.g., winrates, and people who just do not understand the matchmaker system.
They're aiming for giving the game more goals, as well as incentives to play for more casual players. You're making this way more complicated than it needs to be.

> [{quoted}](name=Kumamiki,realm=NA,application-id=Ag8jgd8Q,discussion-id=ffY8IMgK,comment-id=0013000200000002,timestamp=2015-03-11T21:39:14.812+0000)
>
> They're aiming for giving the game more goals, as well as incentives to play for more casual players. You're making this way more complicated than it needs to be.

That may be true. Maybe the goal is just to give people a sense of accomplishment for time invested in the game. To be honest, I was expecting the system to just be a matter of "get X-thousand wins, get a badge" or something like that, focused expressly on number of matches. But it seems they're trying to tie this to "performance", and I'm kind of curious about how they're defining that.

Sure, it's sort of academic, but if people care about these badges, I don't think it's unreasonable to delve a bit deeper. Is the purpose to provide some kind of guidance or education, by rewarding players for focusing on particular subcomponents of the game? (e.g. rewarding great CS, or keeping deaths low?) That would be an admirable goal. Or perhaps they want to reward people for Champion-specific expertise. For instance, if someone is overall Bronze, but plays Xerath at Gold tier, maybe they want to recognize that accomplishment. Or maybe they want to provide some insulation from abuse for people who play a "trash Champion", with the system intervening to say, "hey, lay off, this person actually is a really good Urgot".

I think knowing more about how they measure "performance" will tell us more about what exactly they're aiming to do with this system. My impression is that it's a little more ambitious than just "give badges for playing X games with a Champion".

How do you mean?

The main thought that occurs to me with regard to supports in this context would be the choice of metric. League has long been firm about the idea that, at the end of the match, all that matters is whose nexus blows up. For example, winning a game with a 0/9/2 KDA gives the same MMR boost as winning with 9/0/2 KDA. While good KDA might correlate with success, it's not always so, even for non-supports. For example, sometimes when the team is losing, I'll see people avoid risky plays that might at least give them a shot at victory, and instead focus on protecting their KDA. The MMR system is based on wins, not KDA, and I think that's good.

On the other hand, they might be going for a KDA-based metric here. Maybe that's why they're not putting it on Ranked to start with: they're worried that people will start focusing on KDA instead of nexus explosions, potentially harming their teams in the pursuit of badges. This wouldn't necessarily be a bad move: while there are times when winning the match means hurting your KDA, it may be that people are too quick to assume that their deaths are "worth". If so, this might play an educational role, leading people to more wins by using KDA (or, e.g., CS, or wards placed) as feedback. While theoretically the two measurements could diverge, it may be the case that, especially for lower-ranked players, they'll improve more if you tell them to "just make sure you don't die more than five times" or "focus on getting 300 CS, win or lose".

If they do use such non-nexus-explosion metrics for this system, and encourage people to focus on other factors (like KDA or CS), that could end up being unfair to supports. Even more so than with other roles, supports are all about empowering their teammates (and debilitating their enemies). Sure, the Assist stat represents some of that, but it doesn't directly account for (e.g.) clever warding, or saving teammates from deaths.

I'll reword my last question then as well.

Do the game losses and poor scores affect the point gains enough to make it so you could never reach S rank if you don't play well enough? Or is it possible to play a champion constantly and eventually make it to S rank despite having very little skill with the champion itself?
If everyone can eventually get every character to the highest rank then whats the point. What does this show other than how long you've been playing a character for.

It doesn't. The point is to show that you have enough experience. It either shows that you're good enough to get that high that fast, or that you've played enough games that you should know what you're doing by now. Either way it shows that you're a reliable player and can be trusted
it basically shows that you are less likely to feed as yasuo if you have max tier.

Just one more question if you don't mind me asking;

Is it possible to achieve the highest rank **if** I play **enough** games with a champion X, even if my score **every single game** is 3 kills / 10 deaths / 3 assists??

That's the idea, yeah. This isn't supposed to be a competitive ranking. This is supposed to be "Hey guys, I  really love this champ, look how often I play them!" 

It's similar to Smite's system. Every time you play a god in Smite, you earn some points towards your mastery rank for that god. If you win and do well, you'll get a lot more than if you lose (20+ pts vs 3 pts). As you rank up the mastery you have access to some recolored skins (that are gold and diamond colored), profile icons, and loading banners. 

But this is simply a reward for playing champions you like, not a "LOOK HOW MANY CHAMPS I'VE MASTERED!" If you play a lot of champs, and you play them often, then yeah you'll get a lot of champion mastered icons.

I'm also pretty sure it's going to take a lot of time to get a Rank 5, even if you get nothing but A's.
That what the grade is for

It says you gain points based on how well you do, it says nothing about the possibility of losing the points.

There are 5 grades, and 5 tiers of rewards. Therefore it could be possible that grade actually has nothing to do with how well you do with the champion, just how often you play them. **The only advantage to playing better is you'll earn the points faster.** That's all.

I am also curious about this.  There seem to be many stats that are not currently measured that are critical to playing support well (in addition to other roles).  I have a poll about 3 additional stats that would be useful for many champions/roles here:

http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/gameplay-balance/ZWJU6aYo-poll-new-end-game-stats

Basically they are: 

1) Damage Shielded (self and/or other)
2) CC Time Inflicted (hard and/or soft)
3) Damage to Structures (beyond who gets the "last hit" on a tower or inhibitor)

I think they would be relevant for evaluating how well certain champions were being played.  For example, If you're playing Lulu, or Sona, or even Riven and you're not shielding lots of damage you're probably not playing them right!  Obviously if it's a stomp there won't be much damage for you to shield, but you'll probably get even more points for stomping anyways, so it won't matter if you get less for this specific stat.

Feel free to vote if you think these would be neat to see in the end-game stats screen regardless of use in the new champion mastery feature.
